awd_titl_txt: Area-Selective Atomic Layer Deposition Using Chemisorbed Carboxylate Inhibitors
awd_abstract_narration:
Computer chip manufacturing is the foundation for mobile computing, cloud computing, fifth generation (5G) cellular network technology, artificial intelligence and other applications. Manufacturing computing chips now demands the capability that can place materials on substrates with unprecedented precision in composition, spatial location and dimensions. However, development of such manufacturing capability is still in early stages and demands new enabling knowledge. This award supports fundamental research to generate knowledge for the development of atomic-scale additive manufacturing. This new process enables a scalable method of manufacturing material systems with atomic precise control. Such material systems could also lead to new opportunities such as new catalysts for environmentally-friendly manufacturing and pollution control. The results from this research lead to production of useful, high performance materials and new knowledge to accelerate the development of a novel chip manufacturing process, thus promoting the progress of science and helping the U.S. sustain its leading role in advanced manufacturing. This research is cross-disciplinary and trains students in skills in manufacturing, vacuum technology, surface chemistry, materials science and analytical chemistry. The project involves engaging students, especially, women and underrepresented minorities in research, thus improving engineering education. 

Area-selective atomic layer deposition (ALD) is a key enabling technology to reduce functional device dimensions, reduce manufacturing complexity and cost for integrated circuits and reduce the energy consumption by computing chips. However, the potential of this technology is severely limited by the narrow choices of selective growth chemistries, as well as poor understanding of the heterogeneity of surface chemistry on the selectivity of nucleation in ALD. This research aims at establishing selectively-chemisorbed carboxylate self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) as inhibitors to block or inhibit nucleation during ALD. This research fills the knowledge gap of the inhibition mechanisms and the gradual loss of the inhibitor's ability in blocking nucleation during ALD, and eventually leads to new strategies to improve the inhibitor in blocking nucleation. The collaborative team achieves these goals by studying the formation of carboxylates and selectivity of the nucleation of ALD chemistries with in situ characterizations of the substrate's mass and chemistry, and gaseous byproducts, and with ex situ atomic force microscope-infrared (AFM-IR) spectroscopy to exam the heterogeneity of surface chemistries and establish the relationship of chemistry-process parameter-nucleation inhibition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Fabrication of nanoscale semiconductor devices necessitates exceptionally precise spatial control over thin-film deposition processes. Atomic layer deposition (ALD) is a technique widely employed in the semiconductor industry to achieve this level of precision. However, ALD needs to be augmented with spatial selectivity to ensure that thin films are deposited in specific patterns. Area-selective ALD (AS-ALD) achieves this spatial selectivity by using surface modifications, such as chemisorbed inhibitors, to prevent film growth on certain regions while allowing it on others. The overarching goal of this project was to explore spatial selectivity can be achieved in ALD by utilizing self-assembled monolayers of carboxylic acids, thereby advancing current ALD capabilities and its applications in semiconductor fabrication. With support from NSF grant CMMI 1911276, the team developed an approach that leverages nanoscale infrared spectroscopy to probe the structure and organization of the monolayer under ALD conditions, revealing fundamental insights into the chemistry inhibitor and its role in ALD blocking.

The research team successfully validated the main hypothesis driving this work and demonstrated ALD blocking by carboxylate monolayers. By studying ALD growth of different treated substrates, the team demonstrated that ALD inhibition of long chain aliphatic acids is comparable with other commonly used ALD inhibitors like phosphonic acid. This capability also applies to small molecule carboxylic acids, whose monolayers exhibit ALD inhibition. Taken together, these findings unequivocally establish the viability of carboxylate monolayers as ALD inhibitors for applications in AS-ALD. This work also led to the optimization of nanoscale IR spectroscopy based approaches for characterization of ALD treated thin films, which in turn led to fundamental insights into the change in the monolayer chemistry with ALD cycles. The team identified that nucleation of ALD growth is not related to any major degradation of the carboxylate monolayers but rather to the distribution of the coordination states of the carboxylate molecules to the substrate. More importantly, the inhibition of ALD is correlated to the evolution of the coordination states with ALD cycles, and monolayers that retain a higher proportion of more tightly bound bidentate carboxylates are more effective ALD inhibitors. ALD nucleation is a complex function of many parameters, including surface roughness and monolayer packing. The results from this project indicate that the coordination modes of carboxylates have a more significant impact on the ALD blocking properties than previously known, and is the determinant of ALD growth for surfaces with similar morphological and hydrophobic properties. Application of AS-ALD faces two key challenges, namely the limited selection of suitable inhibitors and lack of understanding of chemistry of inhibitor films when exposed to ALD conditions. The results from this project address both the above challenges by demonstrating the viability of carboxylates for ALD blocking, and the role of the monolayer chemistry towards ALD growth. These results have the potential to enable the use of carboxylic acids as a new class of monolayer forming molecules for AS-ALD, and of nanoscale spectroscopies as suitable techniques for probing the chemistry of buried interfaces, particularly in thin film related applications. The team also validated that similar principles apply to perfluorinated thiolated monolayers: essentially, the structural organization of the monolayer is a key aspect in dictating ALD growth, and films that are resistant to structural alteration are significantly better ALD inhibitors.

This NSF award has been instrumental in letting students develop interdisciplinary intellectual and technical competencies centered on ALD, spatially resolved IR spectroscopy, Atomic Force Microscopy and additional thin film fabrication and characterization approaches. The award supported the training of six graduate students and produced one PhD thesis. In additional, one undergraduate student was trained on the experimental principles of Atomic Force Microscopy and IR spectroscopy through support enabled by this award.

The team, in addition to research activities, also focused on efforts to disseminate the knowledge and advance learning opportunities for the student community at The University of Alabama. A major goal of the group was to engage and encourage undergraduate students to participate in research and learn the fundamentals of spectroscopy and imaging. To that end, the PI expanded on modules on Atomic Force Microscopy and infrared spectroscopy in his senior undergraduate physical chemistry course and interested students from the class were given detailed tours of the lab. This has led to multiple undergraduate students joining the PI’s research group, and this award has enabled the training of one undergraduate student on fundamentals of imaging and spectroscopy. The PI also partnered with the Alabama Materials Institute in Summer 2024 and presented a discussion at the ASM Materials Camp at UA to high school science instructors on polymeric materials, spectroscopy and how high school students can contribute to research efforts in these directions. The long-term goal of the team is to introduce students to the diverse scientific directions enabled by spectroscopic imaging.


Last Modified: 11/29/2024
Modified by: Ayanjeet Ghosh
